WSJ ProPro PE NewsletterPE Daily: Aquiline Makes a Push Into Credit | Secondary Pre-IPO Stock Sales ThriveThis time last year, private-debt investors were bracing for the worst: a wave of defaults and losses from businesses harmed by the pandemic. A year later, private debt looks like a sector in recovery, enjoying a modest fundraising bump in the first quarter and having mostly avoided the widespread Covid-related defaults. WSJ Pro Private Equity’s Laura Kreutzer today brings us news of the first credit fund from Aquiline Capital Partners, the financial and business services technology firm founded by Jeffrey Greenberg, former head of insurance company Marsh & McLennan. The firm raised $230 million for two credit funds, one focused on multiple sectors and one on the aviation industry. Next, we have a story from Yuliya Chernova about the booming secondary market for pre-IPO shares in fast-growing companies and the services providers that help employees sell shares before their company goes public. She spoke with Morgan Stanley’s private-market co-heads about the market for employee shares.

The London-based buyout shop put up the bulk of a $250 million investment in the Swiss company, at a healthy $2.5 billion valuation, as I report today for WSJ Pro Private Equity. The valuation reflects quick growth for the 18-year-old company, which was valued at just over $1 billion about two years ago, in a funding round led by Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
